sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Microalgae are important primary producers and form the basis for the marine food web. As global climate changes, so do salinity levels that algae are exposed to. A metabolic response of algal cells partly alleviates the resulting osmotic stress. Some metabolites involved in the response are well studied, but the full metabolic implications of adaptation remain unclear. Improved analytical methodology provides an opportunity for additional insight. We can now follow responses to stress in major parts of the metabolome and derive comprehensive charts of the resulting metabolic re-wiring. In this study, we subjected three species of diatoms to high salinity conditions and compared their metabolome to controls in an untargeted manner. The three well- investigated species with sequenced genomes Phaeodactylum tricornutum , Thalassiosira pseudonana , and Skel- etonema marinoi were selected for our survey. The microalgae react to salinity stress with common adaptations in the metabolome by amino acid up-regulation, production of saccharides, and inositols. But also species-specific dysregulation of metabolites is common. Several metabolites previously not connected with osmotic stress reactions are identified, including 4-hydroxyproline, pipecolinic acid, myo-inositol, threonic acid, and acylcarnitines. This expands our knowledge about osmoadaptation and calls for further functional characterization of metabolites and pathways in algal stress physiology.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Phytoplankton is estimated to be responsible for roughly 50% of global primary production and forms the basis of the marine food web ( ). Algal cells forming the phytoplankton experience environmental fluctuations in their habitat during sinking or transport by currents. Shifts in nutrient availability, light, and temperature ( ) can lead to a change in the species composition of the phytoplanktonic community. However, these factors also influence the physiology of the persisting cells. In the long term, global warming alters the productivity and composition of phytoplankton ( ). Additional parameters connected to temperature, like dissolved CO 2 and salinity, influence the algae as well ( ). Surface salinity patterns, mainly influenced by increasing evaporation and precipitation or other freshwater influx, are becoming more important on a global level due to climate change ( ; ). Because algae are surface-dwelling primary producers, they are directly affected by such changes in ocean salinity. Considering the importance of phytoplankton for global primary production, it is vital that we understand the effect of alterations in salinity concerning growth, community composition, and metabolism.

A change in salinity in the aqueous environment of a phytoplankton cell subjects it to osmotic stress. This can be alleviated by water flux in or out of the cell or adjustment of the intracellular salt concentration. These salts include inorganic ions and organic compatible solutes, called osmolytes ( ). The accumulation of osmolytes is believed to be the most widespread and long-term successful mechanism of osmoadaptation to increased salinity in free-living algae ( ).

The main body of literature about the identity and quantity of organic osmolytes in microalgae stems from targeted analytics ( ; ). Modern untargeted screening using high-resolution mass spectrometry can offer additional insight ( ) and reveal previously unrecognized metabolic connections. The opportunity to unravel novel aspects in algal physiology prompted us to perform a salt-stress experiment on diatoms and analyze extracts with liquid- and gas-chromatography coupled to high-resolution mass spectrometry in an untargeted manner. This revealed metabolites and pathways responding to salinity changes and allowed us to document metabolic networks connected to osmoadaptation.

For this study, we choose three diatom species – Phaeodactylum tricornutum Bohlin ( Phaeodactylaceae ), Thalassiosira pseudonana Hasle & Heimdal ( Thalassiosiraceae ) and Skeletonema marinoi Sarno & Zingone ( Skeletonemataceae ) – as model organisms. These algae are wellinvestigated with sequenced genomes and a wealth of knowledge on their physiology ( ; ; ). Since different microalgal species may react to hypersalinity with individual changes in their metabolic profile, we aimed to compare the three diatom responses to unravel joint and unique physiological adaptations ( ; ; ). We observed dysregulation of 5%– 46% from all detected compounds. We connect multiple new compounds including 4-hydroxyproline, pipecolinic acid, myo-inositol, threonic acid, and acylcarnitines to osmoadaptation in microalgae.

sec.title: 2. Results
sec.p: To best mimic natural non-limiting conditions and at the same time obtain a high number of cells for extraction, salinity stress experiments were performed with algal cultures in the later logarithmic growth phase. Relatively high salt concentration for the stress (initially 60 PSU) was selected so that it could induce significant changes in the algal endometabolome. We adjusted salinity stress so that it does not lead to algal cell death since otherwise changes in the endometabolome would be associated with cell death processes. The elevation of medium salinity to values close to 60 PSU was previously performed to investigate the effect of increased salinity on the growth, and metabolome of diatoms ( ; ; ; ).

In this study, analysis of the stress response was performed at two time points after salinity increase. A short-term salinity stress response was analyzed 24 h after the stress, which is on average less than doubling time of diatoms ( ). Thus, direct response of the cells was analyzed. The long-term response was examined 96 h after the increase in salt content when algal cells could divide at least two times. Consequently, salinity stress adaptation of the next generations could be examined.
2.1. Effect of the salinity stress on the growth rate of diatoms
To analyze the effect of increased salinity on the growth of the algae, chlorophyll fluorescence intensity and cell density of the cultures were monitored.

P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana tolerated the salinity stress at 60 PSU and exhibited growth during at least four days after the stress ( Fig. S1 , S 2 ). However, lower cell numbers and chlorophyll fluorescence intensity compared to the control were observed (statistically significant p -value < 0.05) for both time points for both diatoms.

Elevation of salinity of S. marinoi cultures led to the dramatic decrease almost to zero in both chlorophyll fluorescence intensity and cell density 96 h after 60 PSU treatment, while the control cultures showed normal growth. Furthermore, this diatom showed no growth under 55 PSU salinity stress ( Fig. S3 ). At 50 PSU S. marinoi cultures showed almost no decrease in both chlorophyll fluorescence intensity and cell density 24 h after the treatment and grew at least 4 day at elevated salinity ( Fig. S4 ). The reduction of chlorophyll and cell counts after salinity stress treatment was statistically significant compared to control cultures for both time points.

Therefore, for diatoms P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana analysis of endometabolome changes in response to salinity increase was performed at 60 PSU and endometabolic changes of S. marinoi were analyzed in response to the salinity increase to 50 PSU.
2.2. Changes in the endometabolome composition of T. pseudonana in response to the short-term salinity stress
Salinity stress led to significant changes in the T. pseudonana endometabolome as indicated by a clear separation in PCA plots of stressed and control cultures after 24 h ( Fig. 1 ).

A volcano plot analysis was conducted to assess significantly dysregulated metabolites ( Fig. S5 , S6). Compounds were considered to be significantly dysregulated in response to the salinity stress when their fold change in comparison to the controls was more than 2 or less than 0.5, with a p -value less than 0.05. In response to the short-term salinity stress, volcanoe plots revealed a statistically significant dysregulation of 102 compounds for the GC-MS results for T. pseudonana , which was around a quarter of all detected compounds. Only three dysregulated compounds were down-regulated; all others increased in concentration (cell count normalized data).

Among the identified metabolites detected with GC-MS, pipecolinic acid and proline exhibited the highest increase in concentration. In total, up-regulation of 11 amino acids was observed. Also, increase in content of 8 sugars (one disaccharide, five monosaccharides, and two inositols) was detected ( Table S1 ).

Statistical analysis of the LC-MS results of T. pseudonana short-term salinity stress response revealed significant increase in concentrations for 50 compounds. That was almost half of all detected compounds, and only of one compound the concentration decreased significantly in comparison to the controls. The most up-regulated among the identified metabolites were arginine, the ectoine precursor N γ- acetyldiaminobutyrate, and ectoine ( Table S1 ).
2.3. Changes in the endometabolome composition of T. pseudonana in response to the long-term salinity stress

In response to the long-term salinity stress, statistically significant dysregulation was shown for 85 compounds detected with GC-MS. Six of them were down-regulated, and the content of 79 was increased (cell count normalized data) (Fig. S7). Among identified metabolites, only citric acid showed a decrease in content, while contents of others were increased. Similar to the short-term salinity stress response, the most upregulated identified compounds were amino acids and amines, including proline and pipecolinic acid. Their fold changes increased compared to the values at the 24 h time point. Also increase of pyrrole-2-carboxylic acid and threonine was observed ( Table S1 ).

Statistical analysis of the LC-MS results for the long-term salinity stress response revealed dysregulation of 39 compounds (Fig. S8). This complementary analytical method confirmed the increase in proline and pipecolinic acid. Also, up-reguation of ectoine and its precursor was detected.
2.4. Comparison of the short- and long-term salinity stress responses of T. pseudonana

The number of significantly dysregulated metabolites detected with both analytical methods decreased over the diatom’ s salinity stress adaptation period. In GC-MS data, 56 up-regulated compounds at both time points were detected. For 29 of them, an increase in fold change during the adaptation was shown. LC-MS results revealed 34 commonly up-regulated metabolites, and the fold changes for 26 of them increased in the sample extracted after 96 h in comparison to the 24 h time point. Thus, for the majority of the common compounds an increase in fold change was detected with both methods 96 h after the stress. Consequently, it can be hypothesized that the reduction in number of upregulated compounds over time is due to them being replaced by higher concentrations of compatible solutes that serve to support cells in long-term stress situations. Examples of such compounds would be proline and two betaines – glycine betaine and proline betaine, which were not among significantly dysregulated compounds 24 h after the stress but up-regulated after 96 h.

The four treatments formed separate groups when control and stress GC-MS samples from two time points were compared in a PCA. In data from LC-MS analysis, there is an overlap in principal components 1 and 2 (samples 24 h control and 96 h high salinity) that was resolved by plotting three principal components ( Fig. 1 , Fig. S9).
2.5. Changes in the endometabolome composition of P. tricornutum in response to the short- and long-term salinity stresses

For P. tricornutum , salinity stress also triggered significant changes in endometabolome composition. Separation between stressed and control cultures was observed in the PCA analysis of GC-MS and LC-MS data for both time points ( Fig. 2 ).

In response to the short-term salinity stress, the statistical analysis revealed an increase in content for the majority of the dysregulated compounds normalized to cell count. Only for one out of 69 dysregulated compounds detected with GC-MS down-regulation was shown, all 89 statistically significant compounds detected with LC-MS were upregulated (Fig. S10, S11).

Among metabolites detected with GC-MS, the highest increase was observed for a putatively identified glyceryl-glycoside in response to short- and long-term salinity stresses. Interestingly, up-regulation of the same metabolite was also detected for T. pseudonana at both time points but with comparatively lower fold changes.

As for T. pseudonana , mainly amino acids and saccharides were among the identified up-regulated compounds. Also, similarly to T. pseudonana , up-regulation of pyrrole-2-carboxylic and threonic acid, ectoine, and its precursor N γ- acetyldiaminobutyrate was detected for this alga ( Table 1 ).

In contrast to T. pseudonana , increased concentrations of methyl palmitate, putrescine, and butyrylcarnitine were detected for P. tricornutum in response to the short-term salinity stress. Interestingly, in response to the long-term salinity stress butyrylcarnitine was not present among significantly up-regulated compounds, but increase in content of another acylcarnitine – propionylcarnitine was detected. Furthermore, statistically significant increase in the content of cysteinolic and pipecolinic acids, methionine, and adenosine was detected 96 h but not 24 h after the salinity stress for P. tricornutum (Table S2).

No clear pattern was found for the long-term adaptation. The amount of significantly dysregulated compounds detected with GC-MS decreased from 69 to 49 during the 96 h salinity stress adaptation of the algae (Fig. S12). For the LC-MS analysis, the number of statistically significantly changed metabolites conversely rose from 89 to 113 in course of time (Fig. S13).

PCA also showed two different trends for GC- and LC-MS analysis. According to the GC-MS results, the endometabolome composition of P. tricornutum was affected to a larger extent by the cultivation time than by salinity elevation ( Fig. 2E ). Cultures extracted at different time points were located further from each other than control and treated cultures from the same time point. Whereas, for LC-MS the clustering of treated and control cultures can be observed. High variation among stressed cultures at 24 h led to overlap with both control at 24 h and stressed cultures at 96 h ( Fig. 2F ).
2.6. Changes in the endometabolome composition of S. marinoi in response to the short- and long-term salinity stresses

Both P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana were subjected to salinity stress of 60 PSU. However, S. marinoi showed no further growth at salinities of 60 or 55 PSU. For this reason, the analysis of the endometabolome composition for this diatom was investigated in response to the increase in salt concentration to 50 PSU where it still grew.

Similar to the results obtained for two other diatoms, salinity stress led to significant changes in the endometabolome composition ( Fig. 3 ). Consitently with the data from the other diatoms, increase in cell count normalized metabolite concentrations was also observed for S. marinoi as a response to the salinity stress.

An increase in amino acid content, especially in proline and 4-hydroxyproline, was detected in salinity stressed cultures of S. marinoi (Table S3). Interestingly, conversely to results obtained for P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana , no saccharide accumulation was detected for S. marinoi in response to the elevation of the salt content at any time point. However, the up-regulation of both myo- and scylloinositols and putatively identified glyceryl-glycoside was observed for S. marinoi in response to the long-term salinity stress. Also, similar to the two other diatoms, the concentration of pyrrole-2-carboxylic acid was increased in stressed cultures of S. marinoi at both analyzed time points.

Furthermore, an increase in the content of four different acylcarnitines was observed for this diatom in response to the short-term salinity stress. Butyrylcarnitine and propionylcarnitine were also detected in P. tricornutum , two others unique to S. marinoi were acetylcarnitine and isovalerylcarnitine. Moreover, similar to P. tricornutum , content of cysteinolic acid increased in salinity stressed cultures at both analyzed time points ( Table 1 ).

Similar to T. pseudonana , an increase in glycine betaine content was observed in high-salinity cultures of S. marinoi . Statistically significant up-regulation of glycine betaine was detected at both time points for this diatom.

Overall, the number of significantly dysregulated compounds detected with GC-MS increased from 21 to 51 over time of salinity stress adaptation (Fig. S14, S16). Almost all significantly increased metabolites after 24 h were also significantly up-regulated 96 h after the treatment (19 out of 21). Conversely, the number of metabolites detected with LC-MS 24 h after the stress was higher than at 96 h time point (62 compounds detected for the 24 h time point, compared to 22 detected for the 96 h time point) (Fig. S15, S17). In turn, 18 out of 22 upregulated metabolites after 96 h were the same as at 24 h. Downregulation was detected only with LC-MS for three compounds 96 h after the treatment. Two of these metabolites (one of them leucine) were elevated 24 h after the stress exhibiting a transient maximum.
2.7. Comparison of salinity stress responses of P. tricornutum , T. pseudonana , and S. marinoi

We compared the amount of unique and shared metabolites regulated in response to salinity stress between the three diatoms. Surprisingly, only ca. 6% after 24 h and 4% after 96 h of the metabolites were common for a salinity adaptation in all three investigated species. This corresponds to 22 common metabolites (8 detected in GC-MS, 13 in LC- MS, and proline detected with both methods) that were significantly dysregulated in all species at least at one time point. All of them were upregulated.

A pairwise analysis shows that P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana share more commonly dysregulated metabolites compared to S. marinoi and T. pseudonana or S. marinoi and P. tricornutum ( Figs. 4 and 5 ). The largest share of dysregulated metabolites was unique for individual algal species and the vast majority of all dysregulated metabolites were upregulated upon salinity increase.

sec.title: 3. Discussion
sec.p: 3.1. Influence of the salinity stress on the growth of diatoms

Salinity is almost constant in the open oceans and varies only little between 33 and 37 PSU. In nearshore waters, however, salinity fluctuations are substantial. Future climate change scenarios predict increased changes in water salinity due to evaporation or reduced freshwater intake from rivers due to low precipitation ( ).

Diatoms can tolerate much higher salinity changes than the salinity ranges of their original habitat ( ). It was, however, observed that an increase in salinity negatively correlates with growth rates and affects the chemical composition of diatoms ( ; ; ; ). We opted to evaluate the physiological and metabolic response of three model diatoms to extreme salinity stress. We initially tested their tolerance to hypersalinity to avoid stress resulting in culture death. After salinity increase to 60 PSU P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana responded with a strongly reduced growth compared to the control. Both algae continued to divide and the chlorophyll content of the culture increased under control and salinity stress conditions ( Fig. S1-S 2 ). This confirms previous findings of salt tolerance for these two algae ( ). S. marinoi was not as tolerant towards increased salinity regimes and did not grow at a salinity over 50 PSU ( Fig. S3-S 4 ). This is in accordance with a survey of Branda, who determined growth of this alga at 5 to 45 PSU ( ).

Kirst suggested that growth rate is affected due to the inhibitory effect of high ion concentration on the metabolic processes. Moreover, the synthesis of organic osmolytes could take resources from general metabolism ( ). The negative effect of the salinity stress on the photosystems could be caused by increased permeability of the thylakoid membrane to ions, including Na + and CI, inhibiting both photosystems. This effect was previously shown in the unicellular green alga Dunaliella tertiolecta ( , ).
3.2. Significantly dysregulated metabolites and their possible interconnections

The most widespread adaptation mechanism of diatoms to osmotic changes in their environment is the adjustment of the cellular concentration of compatible solutes ( ). Many studies address the regulation of such metabolites mainly based on the targeted analysis of candidate compounds. Amino acids and their metabolites are common up-regulated compounds upon hypersalinity stress. Also, organic sulfur compounds, including the dominant dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP), have been quantitatively surveyed ( ; ). We set out here to determine the metabolome changes of three model diatoms with an untargeted approach. This allows the identification of common and unique compatible solutes in the diatoms and linking the dysregulated metabolites to metabolic pathways. We used an analytical approach based on high-resolution mass spectrometry. By combining GC-MS and LC-MS analysis, we could reach an unprecedentedly broad metabolic coverage of up to 344 features with GC-MS and 548 features with LC-MS.

The survey of three diatom species introduced in this study indicates that all of them respond predominantly with increasing concentrations of intracellular metabolites to hypersalinity stress. Only a few compounds were found in lower concentrations, which is in accordance with the concept of increasing intracellular osmolyte production upon hypersalinity stress. We identified surprisingly few metabolites that are upregulated in all three investigated species. These include amino acids, amines and a myo-inositol. Most of these metabolites were previously identified in targeted analyses of diatom responses ( ; ; ). The majority of identified metabolites were, however, unique to the respective species, which indicates a surprising individuality within diatoms. This uniqueness is not caused by their phylogenetic position, with T. pseudonana and S. marinoi belonging to the order Thalassiosirales and the Raphid Bacillariophyceae P. tricornutum to the Baccilariales ( ). Despite this relation, no increased metabolic overlap was detected in T. pseudonana and S. marinoi ( Figs. 4 and 5 ).

sec.title: 3.2.1. Amino acids and their derivatives
sec.p: *For S. marinoi ectoine was detected by evaluation of the ion trace.
**Derivatisation of arginine results in its conversion to ornithine, and these two metabolites cannot be distinguished with the GC-MS method ( ).

Amino acids play an important role as compatible solutes. Accordingly, they comprise the most significant group among the identified dysregulated compounds in response to hyperosmotic stress ( Table 1 ). Their accumulation was explained with continuing de novo amino acid biosynthesis and due to reduced protein synthesis ( ; ). Alternatively, the high content of amino acids in response to osmotic stress could be caused by protein degradation, as shown for higher plants ( ; ).

In many organisms, proline is one of the main osmolytes accumulated in response to hyperosmotic stress ( ). Over time, the increase in proline content was also detected for all three diatoms in this study under increased salinity. Similar responses were previously shown for diatoms, such as the small euryhaline Cyclotella meneghiniana and C. cryptica . These algae accumulate proline in response to the osmotic shock via biosynthesis using arginine and glutamate as substrates ( ). In our study, arginine was also up-regulated by T. pseudonana at both time points.

Accumulation of 4-hydroxyproline and pyrrole-2-carboxylic acid was detected for all studied diatoms. These two metabolites are biosynthetically derived from proline. Accumulation of 4-hydroxyproline in response to salinity stress and its osmolytic function was reported in bacteria ( ; ). Increase in pyrrole-2-carboxylic acid upon salt and drought stress has also been found in higher plants ( ; ). The role as an osmoprotectant in other species points towards a similar role in diatoms.

An increase in lysine content was detected for P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana . This amino acid is accumulated during water stress in plants ( ). In the bacterium Silicibacter pomeroyi , lysine helps to cope with osmotic stress. Moreover, lysine might serve as a precursor to produce pipecolinic acid. This transformation is common for bacteria and plants, where pipecolinic acid plays a role as osmoprotectant ( ; ). Based on the results obtained in this work, the osmoprotectant role of pipecolinic acid is also plausible for diatoms, because its accumulation was detected for all three species.

Ectoine is a heterocyclic amino acid, which acts as compatible solute in halophilic and halotolerant prokaryotes. It is also found in some halophilic protists and microalgae ( ; ; ; ). Ectoine is synthesized from aspartate with intermediate production of N γ- acetyldiaminobutyrate ( ). Elevated levels of ectoine in response to salinity stress were detected for all studied diatoms at both time points analyzed. Accumulation of ectoine was previously described for diatoms, and an increase in its content in response to salinity stress was shown for P. tricornutum ( ; ). Analysis of biosynthetic pathways, enabled by our metabolomics approach, can link the observed elevated levels of N γ- acetyldiaminobutyrate in T. pseudonana and P. tricornutum under salt stress to the up-regulation of ectoine biosynthesis.

For S. marinoi , dysregulation of leucine was detected. Notably, the amino acid was up-regulated in response to the short-term salinity stress and down-regulated in response to the long-term salinity stress. Possibly, this amino acid initially accumulated due to the general reduction of the protein synthesis or protein degradation. Later, it might be consumed in catabolism, providing an alternative source of acetyl- CoA to maintain the general metabolism ( ).

sec.title: 3.2.2. Saccharides and polyols
sec.p: Saccharides and polyols can serve as osmolytes themselves or be used for amino acid biosynthesis. The accumulation of saccharides in response to salinity stress was detected for T. pseudonana and P. tricornutum . Among identified saccharides, glucose, mannose, and cellobiose were common for these two algae. Accumulation of glucose and mannose was previously detected in the diatom Nitzschia constricta when the alga was exposed to a salinity of 50 PSU ( ). In turn, mannose could be a substrate for threonic acid biosynthesis ( ). Previously, accumulation of threonate was shown in response to salinity stress in soybean ( ). An increase in the content of threonic acid was also detected for T. pseudonana and P. tricornutum . Interestingly, the fold change of mannose was higher than for threonic acid. Mannose is not only required for the synthesis of threonate but might play a role as an osmolyte by itself.

In addition to structural and signaling functions, inositols are also known as osmolytes ( ). Durin g myo-inositol bi osynthesis, glucose-6-phosphate is converted to myo-inositol, which protects cells from salinity-induced damage. For instance, kiwifruit accumulate myo-inositol in the first 24 h after salinity stress ( ). In the current study, up-regulation of myo-inositol was detected for P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana at 24 h, and S. marinoi at 96 h. Myo-inositol can be converted to scyllo-inositol ( ). This metabolite is suggested as an osmolyte in, for example, invertebrates of the deep-sea ( ; ). Up-regulation of both inositols was detected for T. pseudonana and S. marinoi .

In conclusion, this work confirms that saccharides are modulated in adaptation to the salinity stress for P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana . For S. marinoi no significant dysregulation of any saccharide was detected.
3.2.3. Quaternary ammonium and tertiary sulfonium derivatives

Quaternary ammonium compounds are another major class of osmolytes ( ). For the algae investigated, quaternary ammonium compounds, such as glycine betaine, proline betaine (stachydrine), and acylcarnitines could be identified among the significantly increased metabolites upon salinity stress.

Up-regulation of several acylcarnitines was detected for P. tricornutum and S. marinoi in response to hypersalinity. For P. tricornutum , an increase in the content of two acylcarnitines was detected after 24 and 96 h. In S. marinoi , four acylcarnitines were in the list of up-regulated compounds 24 h after salinity stress. A study on Lactobacillus plantarum showed that acylcarnitines could play a role as osmoprotectants, although not as effectively as carnitine itself. In contrast to our work, the carnitine derivative up-regulation went ahead with a reduction in accumulated amino acids in the bacteria ( ). If the observed changes in acylcarnitines are connected to osmoadaptation or if they can be considered as a secondary response to altered amino acid biosynthesis has to be clarified in future studies.

Glycine betaine is a compatible solute found in pro- and eukaryotes ( ). Its accumulation in response to the salinity stress was described for several diatom species, including P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana ( ; ; ). During this work, up-regulation of glycine betaine was detected in S. marinoi at both time points and in T. pseudonana at 96 h. Accumulation of proline betaine was detected for T. pseudonana in response to the long-term salinity stress. Its accumulation in response to salinity stress was reported for several plants and algae, including the diatom Nitzschia lecointei ( ; ; ; ).

Interestingly, dimethylsulfoniopropionate, a metabolite often discussed as diatom compatible solute was not among those compounds that were up-regulated according to our criteria. The metabolite was detected in all investigated diatoms but significant up-regulation could not be confirmed. This is in accordance with observations that more subtle osmoadaptations go ahead with the regulation of amino acids and quartery ammounium metabolites, while DMSP, that is highly abundant, only compensates salinity changes under extreme stress conditions ( ).

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: This work addresses the orchestrated metabolic response of diatom metabolism in response to hypersalinity. We can distinguish between universally up-regulated metabolites in all three diatoms under hypersalinity stress that support a common adaptation mechanism. Amino acids, saccharides and inositols were most conserved ( ; ). The majority of regulated metabolites was specific to one or two species. The common repertoire of regulated metabolites is thus accompanied by species-specific physiological responses.

The untargeted screening introduced here allowed not only the detection of previously identified candidates. It led to the identification of several metabolites that were previously not associated with salinity stress response in diatoms, e.g. 4-hydroxyproline, pipecolinic acid, myoinositol, threonic acid, and acylcarnitines. For some of these metabolites their osmoprotectant role was described in plants or bacteria ( ; ; ; ; ). Up-regulation of these metabolites was detected in at least for two of three studied diatoms.

We could also show that certain metabolites were specific for only short-term or long-term adaptation to hypersalinity. The data set introduced here, which is publicly accessible in the MetaboLights database, thus allows identifying common and specific processes in response to hypersalinity in diatoms. It will serve as a basis for future analysis of metabolic re-wiring of these unicellular algae under stress.

sec.title: 5.1. Solvents
sec.p: For endometabolome extraction, LC-, GC-MS sample, and analytical standard preparation (if not stated otherwise), the following reagents were used: methanol (SupraSolv, Merck, Germany ), ethanol (LiChrosolv, Supelco, Merck, Germany ), chloroform (HPLC grade, Fisher Scientific, UK ), acetonitrile (CHEMSOLUTE, Th. Geyer, Germany ), water (Chromasolv Plus for HPLC, Honeywell, Germany ).

sec.title: 5.2. Strains and culture conditions
sec.p: Strains of Phaeodactylum tricornutum Bohlin ( Phaeodactylaceae ) CCMP 2561 and Thalassiosira pseudonana Hasle & Heimdal ( Thalassiosiraceae ) CCMP 1335 were obtained from the Bigelow National Center for Marine Algae and Microbiota (East Boothbay, USA ), Skeletonema marinoi Sarno & Zingone ( Skeletonemataceae ) RCC 75 was obtained from the Roscoff Culture Collection (Roscoff, France ). All cultures are maintained in the algae culture collection of the laboratory.

Cultures were grown in 50 mL cell culture flasks containing 40 mL of artificial seawater medium (ASW) ( ). Stock cultures at the stationary phase were used for inoculation. Starting cell densities were 0.025 ⋅ 10 6 cells mL 1 for P. tricornutum and T. pseudonan , and 0.085 ⋅ 106 cells mL 1 for S. marinoi . The standard temperature was 13 ◦ C and the light adjusted to 55–65 μmol photons m 2 s 1 with 14/10 light/dark cycle; all cultures were incubated with shaking at 80 rpm.

sec.title: 5.3. Experimental design
sec.p: Pre-cultures of the algae were grown in triplicates until they reached stationary phase. Five culture replicates were inoculated for each treatment for the salinity stress experiments. ASW media blanks of the same volume were prepared in duplicates for each treatment. Salinity stress was initiated when cultures were at the late log-phase and the endometabolome was extracted 24 and 96 h afterwards.
For P. tricornutum and T. pseudonana , salinity stress was performed by increasing the salt content in the medium from 35 to 60 PSU as described below.

To establish the upper salt concentration in the medium at which S. marinoi could grow, experiments with three different salt concentrations of 50, 55, and 60 PSU, were performed. Because negative growth was observed for salt concentrations above 50 PSU, the endometabolome analysis was performed for cultures subjected to the salt increase in the medium to 50 PSU.

sec.title: 5.4. Growth curves
sec.p: For growth curve determination, cell amounts and growth rates were monitored by cell counting and chlorophyll fluorescence intensity. Samples were taken once every two to three days during the cultivation period and right before, as well as one, two, and four days after the salinity stress.
Cell counting was conducted using a Fuchs Rosenthal Counting Chamber (Glaswarenfabrik Karl Hecht, Germany ) under the light microscope Leica DM 2000 (Leica Microsystems, Wetzlar, Germany ).

Chlorophyll fluorescence intensity measurement was conducted with a Varioskan Flash spectral scanning multimode reader (Thermo Scientific, Schwerte, Germany ). The excitation wavelength was 430 nm , and the emission wavelength was 665 nm . Measurements were performed in the 96 well-plate format with 200 μL of well-mixed culture per well, each culture was measured in triplicates.
The final cell amount was normalized taking into account the extra medium added during the experiment. Statistical analysis was performed using two-sample t -test.

sec.title: 5.5. Salinity stress experiment
sec.p: To perform the salinity stress experiments, 5 mL of 35 PSU ASW enriched with either 0.135 g mL 1 , 0.180 g mL 1 , or 0.225 g mL 1 of NaCl (Carl Roth, Germany ) were added to 40 mL of cultures and media blanks (35 PSU) to reach the final salt concentrations of 50, 55, and 60 PSU respectively. The same volume of ASW without elevated salt level was added to the control cultures and another set of media blanks. Before addition to the cultures ASW solutions were sterilized by filtration through Filtropur S 0.2 μm filters (Sarstedt AG and Co. KG, Germany ).

sec.title: 5.6. Extraction
sec.p: Extraction of the cultures was performed as described in with modifications. Briefly, after collection of the cells from 40 mL of cultures on Whatman GF/C filters (1.2 μm pore size) (GE Healthcare, US ) under vacuum (750 mbar), the endometabolome was extracted by addition of ice-cold extraction mix (1 mL methanol: ethanol: choloroform, 1:3:1, v:v:v) to the filters in 1.5 mL Eppendorf Safe-Lock tubes (Eppendorf Quality, Eppendorf AG, Germany ). Cells were disrupted with ultrasonication in an ultrasonic cleaner Emmi-D280 (Emag AG, Germany ) for 10 min, and cell debris was sedimented by centrifugation at 30,000 g at 4 ◦ C for 15 min. Supernatants were transferred in 1.5 mL glass vials. Volumes for GC- and LC-MS samples were normalized according to the cell amounts in the cultures. For the media blanks the average volume of the culture’ s samples was prepared. The samples were evaporated under vacuum. Dried samples were kept under argon and stored at 20 ◦ C before analysis.

sec.title: 5.7. Sample preparation
sec.p: Samples for the GC-MS analysis were prepared as described in with modifications. Briefly, dried samples contained aliquots equivalent to 5 • 106 cells and pooled quality control (QC) samples with equal volumes from each extract were reconstituted in 25 μL of pyridine (Chromasolv Plus, Sigma-Aldrich) containing 20 mg mL 1 methoxyamine monohydrochloride (Sigma-Aldrich), heated at 60 ◦ C for 1 h and incubated at a room temperature overnight. 20 μL of samples were transferred into vials with inserts, and to each sample 20 μL of N,O- bis(trimethylsilyl)trifluoroacetamide (Thermo) were added. To one QC samples 1 μL of a C7–C40 alkane standard mix, 100 μg mL 1 in hexane (diluted 1:10 from the 1 mg mL 1 standard from Sigma-Aldrich) was added. Samples were heated at 60 ◦ C for 1 h and directly measured.

For the LC-MS analysis aliquots equivalent to 3 • 10 6 cells and pooled quality control (QC) samples with equal volumes from each extract were reconstituted in 150 μL of a mixture of methanol: acetonitrile: water (5:9:1, v:v:v).

sec.title: 5.8. Standards
sec.p: For GC-MS measurement, samples of standards were dried under vacuum and derivatised in the same way as experimental samples. Final concentrations of standards made up 100 μg mL 1 . To 40 μl of each standard sample 1 μL of a C7–C40 alkane standard mix, 100 μg mL 1 in hexane was added (final concentration of C7–C40 alkane standard mix was 2.44 μg mL 1 ).

For LC-MS measurement, solutions of the standards were prepared by dissolving the standard in a mixture of methanol: acetonitrile: water (5:9:1, v:v:v) with the final concentration of 1 mg mL 1 . N γ- acetyldiaminobutyrate and cysteinolic acid were dissolved in water.
The list of measured standards is presented in the supplementary information (Appendix S1).

sec.title: 5.9. GC-MS measurement
sec.p: GC-MS measurements were performed on a Q-Exactive Orbitrap mass spectrometer connected to a Trace 1310 Gas Chromatograph with a TriPlus RSH Autosampler (Thermo Scientific, Bremen , Germany ). The gas chromatograph was equipped with a Zebron ZB-SemiVolatiles column ( 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm, Phenomenex, USA ). Helium was used as a carrier gas with a flow rate of 1 mL min 1 .

For the electron ionization (EI) mode temperature of the injector was 250 ◦ C, transfer line 250 ◦ C, the auxiliary zone 280 ◦ C, and the ion source 300 ◦ C. For the chemical ionization (CI) mode temperature of the ion source was 180 ◦ C, methane was used as an ionization gas with a flow rate of 1.5 mL min 1 . The injected volume of samples was 1 μL, for EI mode split ratio varied (Table S4), CI samples were recorded in the splitless mode.

Data were recorded in full scan profile mode across a mass range from 50 to 600 m/z in EI mode. Full scan profile mode with a mass range from 80 to 1000 m/z was used for the CI mode, the ionization energy was 70 eV.

Due to the high intensity of the proline peak at the beginning of the GC chromatogram (Fig. S18), split ratios had to be high enough to not overload column and detector. However, detection of low concentrated metabolites was limited at those split ratios. To circumvent this, all samples were injected twice and measured with two different methods. The first method (“Proline method”) was run at a sufficiently high split rate to detect proline without overloading the system and MSacquisition was terminated after elution of proline (Table S4; Appendix S2). The second method (“After proline method”) was run with a lower split ratio, the same temperature gradient (Appendix S3), but acquisition started after the elution of proline. For data analysis, preprocessed data for both measurements were combined, with data up to retention time of proline taken from the first measurement and data after retention time of proline taken from the second one.

sec.title: 5.10. LC-MS measurement
sec.p: Samples for LC-MS analysis were measured with a Dionex Ultimate 3000 system coupled to a Q-Exactive Plus Orbitrap mass spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, Bremen , Germany ). The measurements were performed in positive and negative modes, heated electrospray ionization was used to generate molecular ions. The duration of the method was 14.5 min with an MS runtime from 0.5 min to 9 min. Separation of the samples was performed on a SeQuant ZIC-HILIC column (5 μm, 200 Å, 150 × 2.1 mm , Merck, Germany ), equipped with SeQuant ZIC-HILIC guard column (20 × 2.1 mm , Merck, Germany ). Eluent A consisted of water with 2% acetonitrile and 0.1% formic acid, eluent B of 90% acetonitrile with 10% water and 1 mmol L 1 ammonium acetate. The flow rate was set to 0.6 mL min 1 , the gradient started with 85% solvent B which was held for 4.0 min, gradient to 0% of solvent B (4.0–5.0 min), hold 0% B (5.0–9.0 min), gradient to 100% of B (9.0–10.0 min), hold 100% B (10.0–12.0 min), gradient to 85% of B (12.0–12.5 min), hold 85% B (12.5–14.5 min).
The instrument settings can be found in the supplementary information Appendix S4.

sec.title: 5.11. GC-MS data pre-processing
sec.p: GC-MS data pre-processing was performed as described in . Briefly, raw files were converted into. mzXML format using Proteowizard Suite (proteowizard.sourceforge.net) with vendor peak picking enabled. Data were pre-processed with an R script ( ), which includes the XCMS package ( ), CAMERA package ( ), and MetaMS package ( ). Obtained data was processed further with StatTarget package ( ) for quality control based signal drift correction. All settings were used as published except minimum fragments for features grouping was set to 5 ( ).

sec.title: 5.12. LC-MS data pre-processing
sec.p: Obtained raw data were preprocessed using Compound Discoverer version 3.1 (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The standard workflow (Untargeted Metabolomics with Statistics Detect Unknowns with ID Using Online Databases and mzLogic) with default settings was applied. Peak picking and deconvolution were performed for each algae species experiment separately.

sec.title: 5.13. Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed for signals of which the average peak area of treated or control cultures was at least 5 times higher than in blank samples. Statistical analysis was conducted using Metaboanalyst 4.0 ( ). Data was log-transformed and auto-scaled. Statistically significantly dysregulated compounds were detected using volcano plots with fold change more than 2 and false discovery rate adjusted p -value less than 0.05 with unequal group variance.

Comparison of dysregulated unidentified metabolites compositions between species was performed by comparing retention time and m / z values of the molecular ion for LC-MS results, and retention index, MSspectrum, and m / z value of the fragment with the highest intensity for GC-MS results.

Since for one LC-MS sample of T. pseudonana control culture (extracted 96 h after the treatment) values highly differed from the rest of the samples, the sample was considered an outlier and was not included in further analysis (Fig. S19). One LC-MS control sample of S. marinoi (extracted 96 h after the treatment) was lost during workup.

sec.title: 5.14. Venn diagrams
sec.p: The Venn diagrams were made using the web application BioVenn

sec.title: 5.15. Identification of metabolites
sec.p: Identification of metabolites detected with GC-MS analysis was conducted using the NIST 2011 Mass Spectral Library database (National Institute of Standards and Technology, USA ), MetFrag ( ) and MS-Finder platforms ( ). Results were manually checked for processing artifacts.

Since EI spectra in Orbitrap GC/MS often lack the molecular ion, we supported the identification of candidate metabolites by additional CImeasurements. The CI mass spectra were checked for the presence of molecular ions – CH 4 neutral loss and +C 2 H 5 and +C 3 H 4 adducts to confirm the elemental composition.
The final verification of unknowns was done by comparison of mass spectra and retention index (accepted difference ≤3 units) with analytical standards.

Identification of unknowns detected with LC-MS analysis was performed using Sirius version 4.4.29 ( ). Depending on the tree fragmentation score ( ), and the percentage of CSI:FingerID tool ( ) putative identification of unknowns was performed.

The identity of unknowns was established by comparison of retention time and MS1 spectra with chemical standards (accepted difference ≤0.2 min, < 5 ppm). For betaine, pipecolinic acid, cysteinolic acid, methionine sulfoxide, N , N -dimethylarginine, ectoine, N γ- acetyldiaminobutyrate, acetylcarnitine, propionylcarnitine, butyrylcarnitine, and isovalerylcarnitine also MS2 spectra for both external and internal standards were recorded and compared manually.
